head.title: Sir Ken Robinson: Do schools kill creativity? | TED Talk

meta.name: title
meta.content: Sir Ken Robinson: Do schools kill creativity?
Sir Ken Robinson makes an entertaining and profoundly moving case for creating an education system that nurtures (rather than undermines) creativity.

meta.name: description
meta.content: Sir Ken Robinson makes an entertaining and profoundly moving case for creating an education system that nurtures (rather than undermines) creativity.

meta.name: keywords
meta.content: TED, talks, creativity, culture, dance, education, parenting, teaching, kids

a.class: flex font-bold max-w-max items-start mt-2 text-blue-300 md:mt-0 hover:text-blue-500

div.div: Creativity expert Sir Ken Robinson challenged the way we educate our children, championing a radical rethink of how our school systems cultivate creativity and acknowledge multiple types of intelligence.

Twelve years after Sir Ken Robinson posed this question to the TED audience, head of TED Chris Anderson sits down with Sir Ken to dig in to the changes and progress that have been made in education.","eyebrow":"LISTEN","headline":"Sir Ken Robinson (still) wants an education revolution","imageUrl":"","linkUrl":"https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/sir-ken-robinson-still-wants-an-education-revolution/id1437306870?i=1000426030297&mt=2","published":true,"publisher":null,"status":"APPROVED","type":"EXTERNAL_WEBSITE","visibleUrl":"Apple Podcasts","year":null}]},"primaryImageSet":[{"__typename":"Image","url":"https://pi.tedcdn.com/r/pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/0fa21bf9f73bd5815bf7fcc9f95682ff4e80c6db_2400x1800.jpg?","aspectRatio":"4x3"},{"__typename":"Image","url":"https://pi.tedcdn.com/r/pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/6b6eb940bceab359ca676a9b486aae475c1df883_2880x1620.jpg?","aspectRatio":"16x9"}],"relatedVideos":[{"__typename":"Video","slug":"the_ted_interview_sir_ken_robinson_still_wants_an_education_revolution","id":"30217"},{"__typename":"Video","slug":"sir_ken_robinson_bring_on_the_learning_revolution","id":"865"},{"__typename":"Video","slug":"sir_ken_robinson_how_to_escape_education_s_death_valley","id":"1738"},{"__typename":"Video","slug":"matt_goldman_the_search_for_aha_moments","id":"9048"},{"__typename":"Video","slug":"ricardo_semler_how_to_run_a_company_with_almost_no_rules","id":"2182"},{"__typename":"Video","slug":"emilie_wapnick_why_some_of_us_don_t_have_one_true_calling","id":"2341"}],"customContentDetails":{"__typename":"CustomContentDetails","partnerName":null},"speakers":[{"__typename":"Speaker","avatar":"https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/1465_254x191.jpg","firstName":"Sir Ken","middleName":"","lastName":"Robinson","description":"Author, educator","published":true,"title":null,"whatOthersSay":"","whoTheyAre":"Creativity expert Sir Ken Robinson challenged the way we educate our children, championing a radical rethink of how our school systems cultivate creativity and acknowledge multiple types of intelligence.","whyListen":"

Why don't we get the best out of people? Sir Ken Robinson believed that it's because we've been educated to become good workers, rather than creative thinkers. Students with restless minds and bodies -- far from being cultivated for their energy and curiosity -- are ignored or even stigmatized, with terrible consequences. "We are educating people out of their creativity," Robinson said. It's a message with deep resonance. Robinson's first TED Talk has been distributed widely around the Web since its release in June 2006. The most popular words framing blog posts on his talk? "Everyone should watch this."

A visionary cultural leader, Sir Ken led the British government's 1998 advisory committee on creative and cultural education, a massive inquiry into the significance of creativity in the educational system and the economy, and was knighted in 2003 for his achievements. His 2009 book, The Element: How Finding Your Passion Changes Everything, is a New York Times bestseller and has been translated into 21 languages. A 10th-anniversary edition of his classic work on creativity and innovation, Out of Our Minds: Learning to be Creative, was published in 2011. His 2013 book, Finding Your Element: How to Discover Your Talents and Passions and Transform Your Life, is a practical guide that answers questions about finding your personal Element. And in Creative Schools: The Grassroots Revolution That’s Transforming Education, he reasoned for an end to our outmoded industrial educational system and proposed a highly personalized, organic approach that draws on today’s unprecedented technological and professional resources to engage all students.
